pros: If you have a good leader and can minimize issues at your store, you can pretty autonomously run a store without someone else trying to micromanage you. You can write your own schedules that make sense for the business needs. There's lots of flexibility.
cons: You sacrifice so much as a manager. You may get contacted during your personal time for trivial things until you set proper boundaries with your team. Working with inexperienced employees (as in new to the workforce in general, not just new to the company) can be really difficult in modern times where there is more mentality to be self-made than work for someone else. Although you are in charge of the employees, your work is really determined by what you need to do to make the business successful which can mean working long hours, having to handle last-minute problems. Oh, there's also only one of you in each store so there isn't a lot of options for others to help because your peers in other stores are currently swamped with work too. We don't always get enough time to take care of the massive workload that falls under our responsibility.

pros: Pays full Arizona State University tuition for part time employees.
cons: The pay is terrible. It does not compare to similar competitors that rack in high tips through credit cards. Employee moral is chronically low as the job is high stress, and the turn over is the worst at any job I’ve had. I have worked at my location for a year, and I have had four store managers and the staff has replaced itself twice. Corporate does not care if there are problems in the store unless it affects their bottom line. There always aspects of the store broken, from black specs coming out of the tap, to nitro being down, and having poorly functioning sinks. Unfortunately, as supply chains face disruptions, partners are on the front lines dealing with costumers who will berate you for being out of something beyond your control. High turn over and awful training compounds bad customer interactions because many baristas make drinks different ways. It is said in my location, and I'm sure more, “if they don't complain, it's correct.” I have faced uncomfortable comments for taking too many bathroom breaks, spending too much time in the bathroom and heard conversations sparked by management about cracking down on vaping in the bathroom. I don't even vape. But if I spend too long using the bathroom I will find my or a partners name in the store group chat asking where we are. It's appalling and embarrassing. For a several month period I face sexual harrasment from shift manager. It took nearly six months for him to be fired and I lost hours over it because we share a similar availability. Starbucks preaches about inclusion but we still have to serve homophobic customers. One would use a slur, and not hand a gay barista money because he didn't want to touch him. We only had to stop serving him once he was caught passing counterfeit money. If you care about the environment, you should know Starbucks is the most egregious offender of any company I have worked for. The extreme amount of plastic and waste that we run through is absolutely horrifying, but do not worry, they now have compostable straws. If you can handle being yelled at from all sides, overworked, underpaid, with low satisfaction, Starbuks is perfect for you.

review_title: Great place IF you take advantage of benefits
pros:
The pros are dependent on your individual manager. But in my experience at 5 different stores over 4 years I found that....
- Generally, you are treated well by shifts and management
-Job is generally flexible with your hours if you need
- The benefits are simply really good for the kind of job that it is
-They actually respect your breaks unlike a lot of other food companies
-Despite my cons listed below I HIGHLY recommend this company if you need a flexible job and/or are taking advantage of their benefits. I just graduated with no debt from their ASU college program with my bachelors. So, very grateful for that.
cons:
- Starbucks as a whole has to absolutely update their software infrastructure so that baristas can receive card tips (we only receive cash tips and tips given through Starbucks app). The fact this wasn't done with the recent computer and card reading system hardware/software update is embarrassing. The amount of tips we make in a week is what baristas at Black Rock and Dutch Bro's make in one day.

-Because of the above, and also the pretty low pay for baristas and shifts (this wouldn't be an issue if we got tipped properly like every other single coffee chain company!!) I wouldn't probably recommend working here unless if you are taking advantage of benefits or need flexible schedule.

review_title: They tell you they are different - they are not
pros: Work perks like free drink per shift, very organized by position, whatever position you are put in for the day you know what will be expected of you, lenient with hair colors/tattoos/piercings
cons:
No flexibility in positions - if you are on register don't even think about restocking the cups from the back, try to convince everyone that they have amazing benefits and love their employees but continue to treat them like machines, THE WASTE is absolutely unacceptable - claim to recycle and be a fairly eco friendly company but actually throw all recycling in the dumpster/gallons of milk down the drain because it sat on the counter for less than an hour/throw away any cup or straw or lid that was touched even by clean hands, also the food waste is insane - the shift leads would occasionally "break the rules" and allow me to take home the leftover food/coffee/teas but let me tell you that none of the stores in my area allowed this and did not actually donate the food that they set aside in the little yellow bags

Overall actually working there was just like any other service industry job where they overworked you, underpaid you, and generally treated you as a machine - the issue with Starbucks is that they uphold this image of going "green" and caring about their employees when they are the same as any other large corporation.

pros: The company itself is great, has lots of great benefits (free online tuition! Spotify membership, good food/beverage/merch discounts, decent insurance and other types of coverage, etc.), but the starting pay for a barista ($12) is lower than you earn at Taco Bell in this area, and the job itself is not easy. The training is super fast and you need more time to learn the recipes and procedures, but the overall atmosphere is very positive, kind and understanding of mistakes. I love how baristas are empowered to make decisions like Right-Now Recoveries, where if someone is unhappy or whatever (in general or with their order), you can refund them without asking permission. Quality control is important, they want people to be happy. I like working there, but the pay could be better.
cons: Very physical job, pay isn't terribly competitive for the amount of skill and work you have to do.

review_title: The many joys and frustrations of the Starbucks barista
pros: These are my personal experiences at my one location, and trust, from what I heard my experience was not universal. I loved the people I got to work with, I enjoyed a lot of the customers that came in and in my time there only got actually yelled at by one once. The work is fast paced, tedious, but generally simple enough to turn your brain off and just glide through a shift. The benefits are great, healthcare, stocks, therapy, free coffee and Spotify. I highly recommend it. My main gripe was only that I couldn’t actually ever put any love or time into a latte and even if I did it’d just be lidded and tossed in a cup holder. I love espresso and the practice of making it, but this isn’t the place for that kind of thing.
cons:
-always sticky
-you will make a fool of yourself in front of other people regularly during your first few months
-people can be snippy, especially the “I haven’t had my coffee yet” customers.
-stressfully fast paced, often. 
-it’s a real teamwork oriented system and if you mess up you kinda bring everyone down with you.

pros: The people and the culture at Starbucks is amazing.  IT processes are robust and mature.  There is a an emphasis on documentation here that makes coming up to speed achievable.  Lots of talk about coffee.
cons: Fractured technology landscape where every team "does its own thing".  Middling to low compensation as compared to other organizations.  Frequent long hour days and over-stuffed sprints.  Lots of talk about coffee.

review_title: It’s a good job for now
job_title: Barista/Barista Trainer in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: You become best friends with all your coworkers and make lifelong friendships. Making drinks is my favorite. You get to choose your own availability. I would recommend as a first job.
cons: It’s very exhausting especially if you are a very busy store and it’s non stop. Customers can be absolutely awful for no reason at all. Very frustrating when you are trying to keep up with all the drinks and drive through times and you are out of everything to make those items because you have no one at the moment to support you. Trying to keep up on cafe, mobile and delivery orders all at once when you’re slammed and customers not understanding. Having production shortages and being short staffed. This job can take a big toll on your mental health after a while.

review_title: Company culture has gone down the drain
pros:
- Wage increase every 6 months
- Free mark out every week (bag of beans, box of tea, etc)
- 30% off merchandise (40% off around Christmas)
- Free drink before your shift, during your breaks & after your shift
- 30% off drinks (& food) when you aren’t working
- I made lifelong friends with some coworkers
- Customer interaction with regulars (when they are nice) made the job worthwhile
- Gifted 6-8 SBUX stocks yearly after 1 year of employment (you can also contribute 10% of each paycheque to these stocks) *they do not vest until the following year though - eg. gifted in nov 2022, vests in nov. 2023
- I enjoyed ordering product for the store because I actually understood the volume our store experiences so we rarely ran out 
- Opening and closing is fun, could care less about mid shifts though
- 1st to try new drinks/food
cons:
- Understaffed for high work volume (could have just been my store)
- Crazy & unrealistic expectations (eg. 30 second window times (from ordering at the box to leaving with your order) when the food takes 1+ minutes to warm in the oven
- Coffee culture is non-existent now; they preach for us to create a “third place” and make customer connections but higher management (DMs & RMs) get upset when times are slow
- They give SM roles to external hires rather than those who have been ASMs for years waiting for stores and have worked their way up in Starbucks (personally never experienced this myself because they practically begged me to become a shift after being a barista for 7 months, but I have watched this happen to 4 different ASMs)
- Dependent on your location & manager, they aren’t very accommodating when it comes to your school (even though the company states they are); some will even make you feel bad when you need to book time off for exams or when it’s time to submit a new availability.
- Personally never experienced this, but management would schedule baristas less if they didn’t like them/didn’t want to work with them — I experienced very “highschool-like” behaviour with 2 of 3 managers that managed my store.
- Mondays when management would have meetings with DMs & other stores around the district, they would act like they would lose their job if they left the call to come help on the floor for 10 mins (so we weren’t allowed the bother them during that time)

review_title: Has the potential to be great, but please proceed with caution!
pros:
- Very reasonable health insurance plans with free therapy
- Active job for those who enjoying moving around at work (you will definitely get those 10,000 steps in!)
- Strong effort in team-building (depending on SM or district)
- Learn skills that you can be proud of & continue to develop outside of work
- Amazing connections with the good regulars
- If you find yourself in a really good district, you can really be happy & flourish with the company! A lot of partners that you'll meet have the potential to be friends for life; you'll connect in ways unlike other work environments.
- Especially if you work in a drive-thru location, you become a pro at multi-tasking & handling pressure, which are amazing life/career skills to have!
cons:
- Long hours with minimal breaks
- No care for work-life balance, and many partners are expected to completely shift their personal lives & education around a work schedule that isn't consistent or stable
- You run the risk of being treated poorly by miserable people, both in front of & behind the bar
- Starbucks unfortunately enables aggressive and abusive customers by showering them gift cards when complaints are made & telling employees to essentially "turn the other cheek" when being made uncomfortable in their place of work, only being allowed to stand up for themselves only when customer aggression escalates to threats of violence.
- They preach a "third place" for customers and partners, which in theory is amazing & I'm all for it! Site-roasted coffee & good company was the original goal, and it's a shame the company grew into this negative space for many who have worked under it.
The company seems to now only be interested in making money at the expense of having good, hard-working employees flee to greener pastures. They continue to hire waves of new hires to endure the unfair working conditions, usually high-schoolers or college students with minimal work experience and/or confidence, until they can't stand the mistreatment anymore & leave, rather than nurture & support their partners so that they continue on to having long-lasting fulfilling careers within the company.
- Any growth is minimal, and as you get higher up in the "food chain", the more toxic & cut-throat it becomes. I have seen shift supervisors and store managers alike fired or demoted after years with the company with no notice for no other reason than personal gain. 

As an ex-partner who once loved their job & actively worked towards moving up that ladder, it's just not worth it. Maybe it was at some point, but in the many years I had worked with the company, it only went downhill.

pros: Starbucks makes you interact with each and every customer on a personal level and it will help you come out of your shell. You also get free unlimited drinks during each shift as well as other good beneifts.
cons:
You will get in trouble if they see you not interacting with customers on a personal level. Sometimes people just want their coffee and want to leave or some are just not too friendly.
They focus way too much on the best customer service you could possibly get but not take into consideration how you are feeling if you feel that you are being very mistreated. It’s all supervisors and customers words over yours; even if you are not wrong, you are. We’re treated like workers, not people. You also have to be careful not to greet customers the same way; otherwise they’ll say you sound robotic. And make sure you greet EVERY SINGLE CUSTOMER THAT COMES IN stop what you are doing and look at them while greeting. Also too much cliques and very high school like. A lot of favoritism.

review_title: More work than you could EVER be compensated for.
pros: Good benefits, free food, job is actually pretty fun most of the time.
cons: Pressure to come into work sick. Mentality of your life belonging to Starbucks, your availability always ends up being trashed later and they essentially tell you when you're going to work, even if you're not available. (I've seen this happen to multiple partners, not just me.) Tremendously rude customers with a culture of not just allowing them to abuse you, but encouraging it. Expected to do WAY more than just make coffee. Get ready to scrub floor drains, crawl under counters to clean black mold, and more rotten milk than you know what to do with! Will they hire a janitor or a professional cleaning team to clean the store? NO! You'll do it, usually after store hours with no forewarning and for the same pay rate as the lucky baristas who weren't selected for cleaning. The boss's favorite shift supervisor is only available one day a week and that's perfectly okay, but you want to advance and they'll tell you that you cannot be a shift because you don't have full weekend availability.... To sum it up, there is NO system in place to ensure the workers are treated well or fairly and the overall atmosphere is one of animosity towards anyone that doesn't devote their entire life to the store. I've worked here for five years and despite being agreeable, never losing my temper, and working my butt off, I am usually treated like an afterthought.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in New York, NY
pros:
Benefits
Lots to learn
Fast paced and not boring
The intention of the company

I would only recommend working here if you are looking to learn the ropes. 6 months to a year and then leave. Or work part time for the benefits or for the ASU Tuition reimbursement.
cons:
There are so many cons… I just ..

Mistreatment & Bullying of Employees that flies under the radar/normalized
Changes to the way things are done Every Week, not joking. 
Micromanagement
Every store is managed so different, none of the managers are held accountable to the same standards 
Store managers are the ones that ensure everyone is being treated correctly, HR is a joke, managers therefore can do whatever they want. 
DM’s have NO clue what goes on, always take the managers side even if an issue arises that is absolutely not ok (to save their own butts)
Customers. 
Inconsistent knowledge of recipes. 
Co workers (partners) that are: compliany, know it alls, disrespectful, unprofessional, gossips, lazy, overworked, burnt out, call out, hate their jobs, want promotions but can’t figure how to get them and complain, backstabbers, two faced, fake, etc. 
Managers that are less qualified for the job than your own baristas. 
Horrible Training, can’t even schedule partners to mirror their trainer’s schedule. 
Pay is not enough to deal with all these issues.
Horrible rewards system in place by company, basically non-existent. 
Promotions after supervisor level are so rare they are basically non-existent. 
Gaslighting.
False Promises. 
Managers that sit down in the BoH and do tasks all day while everyone else is dying (some feel bad but don’t care cause that’s what they get paid to do and they can’t solve the companies problems at their level)
Managers that are on call (and get calls & texts all throughout the nights and weekends). 
Supervisors are left to deal with the worst parts of the job, the dirty work, and don’t get paid enough or have a title that is accurate for the work they do. 
Supervisors run the store, the manager is not even needed in the store ( we are key holders ). 
I could go on and on but I digress… Just wonder when changes in the right direction are going to be made. But I can’t stick around to see it.

 I might have PTSD from working here.

pros: Starbucks can be the best place to work or the worst place -- and it's almost completely dependent on your leadership/partners. I work at a cafe store as well, which is helpful because the emphasis is less on wait times than it is in a drive thru store. A little less hectic, but still stressful. Benefits are really great for a job in this sphere, college tuition paid in full at ASU, health care, life insurance, etc etc. Flexible scheduling (if you've got a good manager!) and can be fun when you're staffed and with a capable team.
cons: Constant push from corporate to streamline and get faster/more efficient while also improving customer connection scores which come in every week via survey. Frequently understaffed, every season expected to do more cleaning, more prepping, get drinks out faster AND make sure we connect more with the customer. Can be extremely overwhelming and high turnover rates mean that as an experienced partner you're sometimes the only one with skill on the shift.

review_title: Starbucks Finance - I had enough and got out

cons: Poor Finance Leadership, micro management to the nth degree, obsession over simple details in PowerPoint slides (and not the actual content), a lack of willingness to listen and understand challenges in the current state, unclear objective setting. A team that lacked cohesion, was territorial with processes and unwelcoming to new members of the group. It was the worst private sector experience I've ever had in a Finance organization.

- it's fun. I love my daily job, connecting with customers, forming relationships, and making coffee. 
- Starbucks' company mission is to create a community and positively impact the people who share the "third place" between work and home.
cons:
- huge, huge, huge amounts of plastic waste. Getting rid of straws was fine but almost everyone still asks for them. The amount of single use plastic that is wasted on a daily basis, as well as product waste due to inconsistent management policies, is heartbreaking and contributes so much to pollution and global warming. The company could be doing so much more but just isn't. 
- I don't keep working here for the paycheck. It doesn't cover rent, between the low hourly pay and the inconsistent hours.

cons: Getting to be ASM is very difficult at least in my district. I am not trying anymore, and my significant other has interviewed several times and asked to do things that he already does daily. It always seems like a way to take advance of harder work for less pay for “growth”. Otherwise sometimes the team can be lazy or incompetent and training isn’t involved like it used to be. If you aren’t interested in the benefits, the pay is not very competitive and the incentive structures aren’t there for day to day goals.

pros:
In my experience and opinion, your authentic self is a goal, and encouraged here at Starbucks. 
Working alongside people who will help, support, and encourage you, and vice versa, is also a huge plus. 
Genuine friendships are made among partners across stores🥰
In my experience so far, you really feel like your team has eachother’s backs.
You get benefits, though you are part time! Unheard of in the best way!
...And of course you get your free drink and food mark outs.
cons:
The pay- You and your team all do so much on a daily basis, but for not much at all.
The hours- unfortunately, it seems that unless you’re on track for becoming a trainer, or you’re a shift or manager, you can not have more than “x” amount of hours in a week. 
The turnover- at both my stores(I transferred from my OG store when I moved), there seems to be a larger turnover rate. But, on the flipside, we are retail.
Burn out- it’s unfortunately a thing. I saw it at both stores. We constantly run into not having enough staff so we all work so so much and at such a speed and over time that wears and I think that's a factor in people deciding to leave.

review_title: A decent job, still a corporation
pros: I have always had decent luck with my managers and never had a problem with them as long as I worked hard. The coworkers have always been a saving grace, I think Starbucks attracts some pretty cool people to work with. I have also met a lot of cool customers, and the benefits they provide at 20 hours is pretty amazing. I have had a good time working with this company overall, and have been able to take advantage of what they have to offer.
cons:
It's still a corporation and in the big picture Starbucks doesn't care about it's employees. The higher up the food chain you go, the district managers, regional directors, and so on, are completely out of touch with what it's really like to work in their stores. They push managers to do more business while cutting labor. They bully the good leaders into quitting or demoting because it's simply not worth it when they know what it's like to be a barista/supervisor and the higher-ups still want them to treat us like we're disposable. 

If you don't expect anything more than a fast-food job with a better work environment, you are golden. But don't go in expecting Starbucks to treat you like you're valuable. It's a job working for a huge corporation, and the only thing they will care about in the end is profits. Don't drink the KoolAid. Respect yourself.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in North Canton, OH
pros:
Free beverages during shift... That's it.
They used to have a culture based on inclusion and connection, but since a little before the pandemic, all corporate cares about is the bottom line: profits. Wish they would focus more on that third place culture.
cons:
Like other places, requests for days off were treated simply as that: requests. Would get denied, leading you to calling off and getting strikes held against you.
They expected you to bend over backwards for them, asking you to come in on your days off and work double shifts.
Pay was atrocious for the amount of work. Never gave employees full time status, but expected you as part timers to work virtually everyday. Constantly blowing up your phone when people called off.
Majorly understaffed...always. Oftentimes would lead to people working through their breaks and not having time to use the restroom. Absolutely ridiculous to put your employees through that kind of stress.

pros: There's flexible hours and easy to contact management
cons: Management will be on you about drive times. You didn't have a 20 second window time? Death sentence. If you're on nights you are running with a skeleton crew of 2-3 people and if you get slammed between the hours of 3-9 odds are there are only 4 of you and you're dealing with peak-time levels of customers. Customers have been bred by the corporation to despise their baristas and treat them like absolute garbage. Playing mask police with customers was hell. If a customer tries to fight you or throw things at you, you just have to stand there and take it or odds are you'll be fired. Even then if a customer broke all of your bones and peed on your writhing body, the company would give them a discount the next time they came in and leave you to die. review_title: Good job to be a barista, wouldn’t recommend advancement.
pros: It started out fun when I was a barista but when I advanced to be a shift manager it was an entirely different story. It’s too much of a transition from barista to shift manager, my responsibilities went up to the point where I couldn’t handle it and was constantly stressed out. I transferred to different stores twice as a shift manager hoping it would get better and it didn’t, my store managers would not support me enough. I wanted to become a store manager and move my way up at one point but I wasn’t enjoying it so changed my mind and tried to stick it out as a shift manager. I got told I should “step back down “ to a barista because I wasn’t doing a good enough job for the company, that was my wake up call to find another job and quit. Too many expectations there are unrealistic as a shift manager and it just wasn’t worth it. I wasn’t happy. Only a certain kind of person can succeed beyond a barista so it’s not something I’d recommend! If you work for Starbucks you should do it for fun as a barista! The company has awesome benefits and the people I worked with were awesome! A very good company to add to a resume!
cons: Being a shift manager is too hard with too many expectations, it can get too stressful and it just wasn’t worth it. I don’t recommend advancement for Starbucks unless you want to get constantly reprimanded by your store manager.

review_title: Overworked, Underpaid, Stressed, Dismissed, Unfair Working Conditions in a Pandemic!
pros: My regular customers were great, they made it bearable to continue working here as did mostly all of my coworkers.
cons:
- Was told to come in when showing 3-4 COVID symptoms multiple times myself and other partners as well.

- Scheduled outside of my documented availability multiple times and being told I need to find someone to take the incorrectly scheduled shift 
- manager being rude when frazzled, customer complaints about them and the whole staff has had at least one bad interaction with him
- NEVER ENOUGH STAFF
- Working in dangerous snow storms because we are "scheduled" so try harder people need coffee
- manager standing literally right behind you and staring while asking how much longer as you prepare an item that was ordered 45 seconds ago and they stare at your DT times.
- I personally just felt like I wasn't cared for at all working here during the pandemic, Starbucks preaches about the importance of community and fostering a safe environment for all but does not include their partners into this at all. We weren't even paid enough to be considered essential frontline workers and put ourselves, families and communities in danger. 
Overall, this job physically, emotionally and mentally drains me. I cry at work, before getting there and after I leave most days. It's June and I've used all my free sessions from Lyra that Starbs gives employees (obvious reasons why)
We were given the slightest raise at some point in the last year but think about how Starbucks has completely bounced back as a company from the pandemic yet partners are still being overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Grateful for my time with Starbucks but glad I left
pros: Free coffee, solid benefits, and a real sense that at its core the ideal is that they live up their values. Starbucks attracts good talent that are passionate about their jobs and its shows in their execution if their role. Starbucks also has top of class development from barista to shift supervisor to ASM and Store Manager. A fantastic first management role for anyone without previous experience to develop in the company.
cons: No work/life balance for salaried leadership, no development prospects beyond a store manager, and support from district managers really varies district to district. Annual pay increases also do not keep pace with inflation. Starbucks policies around attendance don't allow manager to hold hourly employees accountable to coming to work so stores are chronically understaffed even when on paper they should not be.

review_title: Will Prepare You For A Lot
pros:
- You will start to understand ways to appease a customer, which is a very helpful skill
- Prepares you to work the frontline in restaurant as well as gets you used to hectic duties of a kitchen or a bar
- Great for gaining experience
cons:
- Issues often not taken seriously (I hurt my ankle while working here, and it just got progressively worse and the staff brushed it off as me trying to get out of work while I was trying not to cry about how much pain I was in - of course, it was my choice to come in, so I quit shortly after because I was not gonna permanently damage my body, but that was not an acceptable reason to leave according to my supervisor)
- Open homeless policies while generous and an admirable effort, sometimes left me feeling in danger in a city like Sacramento
- The garbage at my location was a block away and really uncomfortable to walk to by yourself in an alleyway. Staff often made jokes about finding people inside of there as if that wasn't terrifying.
- Overall, just felt like they didn't care about the wellbeing of everyone who worked there
- Not a great long term job, as health both physically and mentally are not prioritized
